{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3503786,"name":"Nathan Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T04:37:07.955Z","cooked":"

So on Team Update 09,

R703 Use specific Ethernet port for roboRIO. The roboRIO Ethernet port must be connected to

A. the wireless bridge port labeled ‚Äú18-24v PoE‚Äù for OpenMesh radios (either directly, via a network switch, via an RPM, or via a Cat5 Ethernet pigtail).
B. the port labeled ‚ÄúRIO‚Äù of a VH-109 radio via (either directly, or via a Cat5 Ethernet pigtail) an RPM, passive PoE injector cable or adapter (whether or not it is used to power the radio), or an Ethernet cable with the appropriate wires removed on the roboRIO end. All wires or adapters used must be fully insulated.
C. the port labeled ‚ÄúAUX 1‚Äù or ‚ÄúAUX 2‚Äù of a VH-109 radio with the corresponding DIP switch in the off (default) position (either directly, or via a Cat5 Ethernet pigtail).

Seems like a network switch between roboRIO and VH-109 is no longer allowed. RoboRIO must be connected to radio directly (and if using RIO port, POE should not be feed into roboRIO).

NathanZhou:

(either directly, via a network switch,

It has an exemption specifically for a network switch in the connection it is talking about.

That‚Äôs only under the OpenMesh entry. I‚Äôm inclined to agree that it‚Äôs likely the intent of the rule to allow it for both, but we can‚Äôt act on what we think the intent of the rule is, only what is written.

This is a win in my opinion, one less point of failure that leads to a feels bad moment.

Switch power and switch connections we‚Äôre definitely the next biggest reason for loss of communications during a match after radio reboots last year.

Honestly, now that the radio has multiple ports that actually work, I‚Äôm not sure why you would risk running your main connection between the robot and the field through a secondary device like a switch. Yes, you have to run an extra Ethernet cable, but to me that‚Äôs a minor trade-off for the peace of mind of a robust main connection with minimal points of failure. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend doing it even if it was legal.

I‚Äôm confused, are network switches banned outright for VH-109 radios?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-02-07T21:36:59.539Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":49.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485402,"topic_slug":"r703-in-team-update-09-switch-no-longer-allowed-between-roborio-and-radio","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6593 Alumni/Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/r703-in-team-update-09-switch-no-longer-allowed-between-roborio-and-radio/485402/7","custom_user_title":"6593 Alumni/Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3505450,"name":"Nathan Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-07T21:38:53.254Z","cooked":"

No. The only requirement is you connect your roboRIO directly (with special wire / dip switch in requirement on POE) to the radio without using a switch. You could still use a switch for other custom electronics inside your robot (for example, cameras, sensors and co-processes).
